column1: 136534544470900736;"benohanlon#1119";"27-Aug-18 11:42 AM";"Please share this AMA on crypto-conditions with any dev / blockchain communities that you're involved with if you'd like to help me spread awareness. JL777 will be answering questions. https://www.reddit.com/r/komodoplatform/comments/9ahddj/ama_monday_27th_august_to_talk_about/";"";"";

column2: wondering if inheritance will be or perhaps is implemented? Where functions can be preserved and called on later.";"";"";

column1: 455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:12 PM";"what exactly do you mean. ""inheritance"" does not exist in the crypto conditions standard";"";"";

column2: calling on the properties of a parent contract without having to redefine them all.";"";"";

column1: 364559422594482176;"Anthony#6143";"27-Aug-18 12:29 PM";"The question is if with crypto conditions
column2: if it will be built with the ability to inherit properties or functions from other cc contracts";"";"";

column1: 455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:31 PM";"please keep in mind that utxo based CC contracts are a totally different animal than solidity. That being said
column2: you can write one CC contract that knows about another CC contract and in essence be invoking it";"";"";

column1: 455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:32 PM";"for example there is the assets CC that allows to issue and trade tokens. Another contract could issue tokens and then use the newly issued token as trigger conditions for invoking the payments CC contract.";"";"";
455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:32 PM";"I think the way to view it is that each CC contract adds more functionality to a blockchain
column2: which in turn can be used by users directly or by other contracts";"";"";

column1: 455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:33 PM";"it is not direct source level inheritance";"";"";

455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:35 PM";"I have explained in detail how the CC contracts work. It is a good idea to not have preconceptions and start with a fresh mind: https://github.com/jl777/komodo/blob/FSM/src/cc/CC%20made%20easy";"";"";
364559422594482176;"Anthony#6143";"27-Aug-18 12:35 PM";"It is about 1300 lines of code to roll the dice in your example with CC
column2: with solidity you can do it in 200 lines because you can call on the function that was written prior about rolling dice by someone else";"";"";
solidity is a higher level language than the C code I wrote";"";"";

column1: 364559422594482176;"Anthony#6143";"27-Aug-18 12:36 PM";"So I was asking if it is or will be possible to consolidate code and preserve code already written so it can be called on by someone in the future";"";"";
455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:36 PM";"that is not to say a less line count CC contract cant be done by ahigher level language";"";"";
455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:36 PM";"the way for that is to make reusable functions
column2: like in CCutils.cpp
column3: and eventually we should have a library of functions to do standard things";"";"";

column1: 364559422594482176;"Anthony#6143";"27-Aug-18 12:37 PM";"So what I see is that crypto conditions is in addition to blockchain consensus";"";"";
364559422594482176;"Anthony#6143";"27-Aug-18 12:37 PM";"the code is programmed into the blockchain etc";"";"";
455741312273219595;"jl777c#5810";"27-Aug-18 12:37 PM";"plz keep in mind these are the initial 4 CC contracts
column2: very early in the lifecycle and rather than try to reduce the lines of code
column3: I made each one have no dependencies on any other
column4: that way the entirety of what is needed is seen";"";"";
